question: You are on site and you need to dispose of some waste liquid which has oil in it and you are not sure what to do with it. What should you do?

options.label: A
options.text: Dispose of it in a sealed container into the site skip

options.label: B
options.text: Pour it onto the ground, it will soak away

options.label: C
options.text: Take it outside and set light to it

options.label: D
options.text: Ask your supervisor about the correct way to deal with this waste

question: How should you get rid of hazardous/special waste?

options.label: A
options.text: Put it at the bottom of any site skip

options.label: B
options.text: In accordance with the correct site waste rules

options.label: C
options.text: Take it home, they won't want it on site

options.label: D
options.text: Take it to the nearest local authority waste tip

question: Which of the following is classed as hazardous/special waste?

options.label: A
options.text: Non-asbestos insulation

options.label: B
options.text: Polythene and shrink wrap

options.label: C
options.text: Empty cement bags

options.label: D
options.text: Fluorescent light tubes

question: Which of the following should be disposed of as hazardous/special waste?

options.label: A
options.text: Timber, plywood and MDF off-cuts

options.label: B
options.text: Glass fibre insulation

options.label: C
options.text: Aerosol sealant canisters

options.label: D
options.text: Used nuisance dust masks

question: You need to clean up some oil that has leaked from machinery onto the ground. What is the right way to do this?

options.label: A
options.text: Put the oily contaminated soil into the general waste skip

options.label: B
options.text: Put the oily contaminated soil into a suitable container that takes hazardous waste

options.label: C
options.text: Put it under some off-cuts so that the oil cannot be seen

options.label: D
options.text: Wash the oil away with water and detergent

question: Other site workers are complaining that you are generating too much dust. What should you do?

options.label: A
options.text: Tell them you have nearly finished

options.label: B
options.text: Stop work and inform your supervisor

options.label: C
options.text: Ignore them – it’s none of their business

options.label: D
options.text: Issue the other site workers with dust masks

question: Who needs to understand relevant environmental risks on a construction site?

options.label: A
options.text: Only the principal contractor

options.label: B
options.text: Only the subcontractors

options.label: C
options.text: Everyone working on the site

options.label: D
options.text: Only the environmental clerk of works

question: Under environmental law, which statement is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Companies and individuals can be prosecuted if they do not follow the law

options.label: B
options.text: Companies can be prosecuted, but not individuals

options.label: C
options.text: It is legal to transport business waste without proper paperwork

options.label: D
options.text: It is legal to disturb protected species’ habitats

question: Do individuals have any responsibility for sustainability when on site?

options.label: A
options.text: No, it is dealt with by the site manager

options.label: B
options.text: No, it is a matter for the Environment Agency/NIEA/SEPA

options.label: C
options.text: Only on sites where there is asbestos

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, on every site

question: Which of the following is NOT best practice from a sustainability point of view?

options.label: A
options.text: Saving materials, fuel, water and energy

options.label: B
options.text: Looking after the people working on or near the site

options.label: C
options.text: Protecting the environment

options.label: D
options.text: Sending unused and waste copper cables to landfill

question: Which of the following does NOT help sustainability during construction projects?

options.label: A
options.text: Leaving engines and motors running when they are not needed

options.label: B
options.text: Segregating waste

options.label: C
options.text: Vehicle sharing or using public transport to get to work

options.label: D
options.text: Avoiding overheating site huts

question: Which of the following should you do on site in the interest of sustainability?

options.label: A
options.text: Run plant and equipment when they are not needed

options.label: B
options.text: Bury waste material

options.label: C
options.text: Comply with site instructions on handling waste materials

options.label: D
options.text: Pour waste liquids down a drain off-site

question: Which of the following is NOT part of ‘environmentally-friendly’ construction?

options.label: A
options.text: Creating a dust nuisance to residents in neighbouring properties

options.label: B
options.text: Preventing water and soil pollution

options.label: C
options.text: Saving energy

options.label: D
options.text: Minimising the amount of waste you create during a job

question: From an environmental point of view, why should materials be reused, where possible?

options.label: A
options.text: To save the client money

options.label: B
options.text: A lot of energy and raw materials go into making most construction products

options.label: C
options.text: It makes less mess on site

options.label: D
options.text: It’s a European Union Law

question: Which action will help to minimise waste?

options.label: A
options.text: Only take or open what you need and return or reseal anything left over

options.label: B
options.text: Use new materials/packs at the beginning of each day

options.label: C
options.text: Leave materials unprotected in the rain

options.label: D
options.text: Always order much more than usually required – just in case you need it

question: Which of the following is good environmental practice?

options.label: A
options.text: Over-ordering materials

options.label: B
options.text: Segregating waste into different types

options.label: C
options.text: Leaving skips uncovered in wet weather

options.label: D
options.text: Leaving motors running when they are not needed

question: Do individuals have any responsibility for minimising the amount of waste created on site?

options.label: A
options.text: Only if asbestos removal is being carried out

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, everyone on site has this responsibility

options.label: C
options.text: No, it’s the responsibility of the client

options.label: D
options.text: Only during site clean-up, at the end of the project

question: If you have unused material left, what should you do before you consider putting non-hazardous waste items into a skip?

options.label: A
options.text: Make sure there is a label on it

options.label: B
options.text: Put it in a plastic bag and put it in a skip

options.label: C
options.text: Check whether someone else on your team can make use of it

options.label: D
options.text: Weigh it

question: Why should different types of waste be separated on site?

options.label: A
options.text: It will take up less room in the skip

options.label: B
options.text: So the local council can charge Landfill Tax

options.label: C
options.text: So the main contractor can check what’s being thrown away

options.label: D
options.text: So waste can be recovered more easily

question: When storing liquids (such as oils, fuels or chemicals) on-site, what must you do?

options.label: A
options.text: Always use the nearest container

options.label: B
options.text: Use a transparent container so you can check how much liquid is in it

options.label: C
options.text: Ensure the liquid material is stored safely and securely, and out of the way of site traffic

options.label: D
options.text: Keep the tops off, to prevent pressure from building up

question: What can help to prevent harm to the environment from oil spillages?

options.label: A
options.text: A supply of water to flush the spill away

options.label: B
options.text: Cover the spillage with soil

options.label: C
options.text: Turning liquid containers upside down so the top can’t come off

options.label: D
options.text: Store oils in an area that can catch any spills, such as a bund or a drip tray
